evidence_span: The long-term water autoclave weight gain data and in-PWR oxide thickness measurement data presented in this paper demonstrate the improvement in the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 with a decrease in the tin content of the material

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: In-PWR measurements seem to segregate into two groups. One group is the high-tin data for Variants 1, 2, and 5, and the other group is the low-tin data of Variants 3 and 4.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: This data comparison supports the suggestion [36] that a long-term 633 K water autoclave corrosion test is a good screening test for ranking the in-PWR corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 variants.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: A comparison of Variants 1 and 2 is useful to evaluate the effect of annealing process variation in high-tin Zircaloy-4.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The autoclave data in Fig. 1 shows no difference in weight gain for these two variants, while the in-PWR oxide thickness data (Fig. 4) show that a higher annealing parameter may improve the corrosion resistance slightly.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The autoclave data in Fig. 1 shows no difference in weight gain for these two variants, while the in-PWR oxide thickness data (Fig. 4) show that a higher annealing parameter may improve the corrosion resistance slightly.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: A similar comparison for low-tin cladding variants shows that the lower annealing parameter, Variant 3, has slightly bcs ecav  hilxihis 4) show no effect of annealing process variation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: These comparisons show that any efect of annealing parameter variation (within the investigated range) on the corrosion rate, if it exists, is minor.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Relative insensitivity of cladding corrosion to annealing parameter variation in the range of approximately 1 to 4 × 10^-17 h (with Q/R = 40000 K) is consistent with the results reported by Garzarolli et al. [5].

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor A has a nominal coolant inlet temperature of about 569 K and operated with reactor cycle lengths of from about a year to 18 months.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor B's coolant inlet temperature was slightly lower, at about 563 K.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Reactor A and B both had an average subchannel coolant mass velocity of about 3730 Kg/m²s

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The ESCORE PWR corrosion model describes corrosion as a two-stage process. An initial period of nonlinear time dependence (pre-transition) is followed by a period of linear time dependence (post-transition).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: The thickness at transition is dependent on temperature at the metal oxide interface and generally lies in the range of 2 to 3 μm for the oxide thicknesses of interest.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Subset A, Reactor A, 3 cycles, 10 rods, 37.3 to 48.1 GWd/MTU, high tin content, EPB fabrication, 1.31 normalized pre-exponential multiplier

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk5
evidence_span: Subset A, Reactor A, 2 cycles, 8 rods, 22.5 to 31.3 GWd/MTU, high tin content, EPB fabrication, 1.03 normalized pre-exponential multiplier

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: For 1.5% Sn, the corresponding number is 3.8 x 10^21.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: The number of vacancies in oxygen deficient zirconium oxide (ZrO2-δ) on 100g of Zirconium at 300°C is estimated to be 6.86 x 10^20.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: The observed effect of tin level on the uniform corrosion resistance of Zircaloy-4 is consistent with an average valancy of Sn atoms dissolved in ZrO2 to be lower than four.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: Therefore it is possible to associate the lower corrosion resistance of high-tin Zircaloy-4 with the introduction of additional vacancies in the oxide due to the tin addition to zirconium.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: A pressurized water reactor (PWR) facility has been used to determine the effects of high (4 to 4.5 ppm) lithium on the corrosion behavior of Zircaloy-4 cladding material exposed to nucleate boiling (1% void) and to one-phase cooling conditions.

conditions.medium: PWR coolant with high lithium (4 to 4.5 ppm)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: The test employed four fuel rod segments, base-irradiated to an average burnup of 28.5 MWd/kg UO2 in a commercial power plant, and with average initial oxide layers of either 10, 20, or 40 μm respectively.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: Average oxide layer increases of 30 and 55 μm were observed for the rods exposed to one-phase cooling and nucleate boiling conditions, respectively.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_043_chunk9
evidence_span: Average oxide layer increases of 30 and 55 μm were observed for the rods exposed to one-phase cooling and nucleate boiling conditions, respectively.
